elements.title: Warm Containment: Rounded Containers as Civilizational Boundaries
elements.problem: The host journey demands escalating surrenders of private space into public marketplace artifacts. Freud identifies that civilization requires 'beauty, cleanliness and order' -- but when the visual language feels cold, clinical, or institutional, the host experiences the platform's demands as extraction rather than protection. Flat, sharp-cornered containers with thin gray borders read as bureaucratic forms. The host's instinctual resistance to 'cultural privation' intensifies when the visual environment signals authority rather than safety. The user stories confirm this: 'Value before the ask -- always.' If the visual surface itself feels like a demand (sterile, impersonal, corporate), the host's System 1 rejects the environment before any content is evaluated. The challenge is to make structured layouts feel protective rather than restrictive -- to visually embody Freud's insight that civilization should offer security in exchange for the instinctual sacrifices it demands.
elements.solution: Use rounded containers (--rounded-xl: 12px or --rounded-2xl: 16px) with warm-tinted backgrounds (--bg-off-white: rgb(252, 250, 255) or --protocol-surface: #F7F2FA) and subtle purple-tinted shadows (--shadow-purple-sm) as the primary containment pattern across all journey phases. These containers represent the boundary between private and shared space -- they hold the host's information within a visually warm enclosure that signals 'your data is safe here.' The rounded corners soften the civilizational demand; the warm tint distinguishes the platform from cold transactional surfaces (banking, government, legal). Every card, wizard step, proposal view, and dashboard section should use this containment pattern consistently. The border should use --border-color (#e5e7eb) at 1px, never heavy or dark borders that feel like constraint. The interior should always have slightly more generous padding (--spacing-2xl: 24px minimum) to create breathing room -- Freud's 'order' requires that the host never feels visually crowded by the platform's demands.

evidence.quote: We soon become aware that the useless thing which we require of civilization is beauty; we expect a cultured people to revere beauty where it is found in nature and to create it in their handiwork so far as they are able.
evidence.insight: Freud identifies beauty as a non-utilitarian requirement of civilization. The platform's visual containers are not just functional (holding content) but civilizational (demonstrating that this marketplace values beauty, cleanliness, and order). Rounded, warm containers signal that the platform is cultured -- that it treats the host's space with the reverence Freud describes.

evidence.quote: Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first. Offer to refine after.
evidence.insight: The visual container must communicate warmth and safety before the host reads any content inside it. The warm background tint and rounded corners provide a pre-cognitive 'value before the ask' signal: the environment itself feels welcoming before the host encounters any demand. This is the visual translation of Rod's principle.

evidence.quote: --bg-off-white: rgb(252, 250, 255) -- Subtle purple-tinted background. --rounded-xl: 12px -- Prominent cards. --shadow-purple-sm: 0 2px 4px rgba(49, 19, 93, 0.2) -- Subtle purple glow.
evidence.insight: The production style guide provides the exact tokens for implementing warm containment: the off-white carries a subtle purple tint (not cold gray), the rounded-xl radius softens card edges, and the purple-tinted shadow creates a warm glow rather than a harsh drop shadow. These tokens, used consistently, create the visual language of protective enclosure.

new_tokens_needed: --container-bg-warm: a token alias mapping to --bg-off-white for semantic clarity, so designers select 'warm container background' not a raw color value

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: container backgrounds (--bg-off-white at rgb(252, 250, 255)) must maintain minimum 4.5:1 contrast ratio with body text (--text-dark: #1a1a1a achieves 15.8:1). Border color (#e5e7eb) is decorative, not informational, so no contrast minimum applies. Purple-tinted shadows are ambient, not content-bearing.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The container edge (rounded border + shadow) is perceived first, establishing the safe enclosure. Then the warm background registers as ambient temperature. Content inside is read third. The eye should never see content floating uncontained -- every piece of host data lives inside a warm container.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Warm, not cold. Soft backgrounds, not stark white.' and 'Trustworthy, not corporate. Rounded corners, human language, real data.' The warm containment pattern is the direct visual implementation of both principles. The purple-tinted background connects every container to the brand palette without requiring overt purple usage.

elements.title: Purple Gradient Authority: Premium Stability Through Brand Color Hierarchy
elements.problem: The host is evaluating whether this marketplace is worth the instinctual sacrifice of sharing their private space. Freud's Ch V identifies that 'civilized man has exchanged some part of his chances of happiness for a measure of security.' The visual language must make this security tangible. If the primary brand color reads as playful, cheap, or inconsistent, the host's System 1 assessment fails: this platform does not look serious enough to trust with my property. The production style guide uses a deep purple palette (#31135D primary) that inherently signals premium stability -- but the visual system must deploy this purple with discipline. Purple used everywhere becomes wallpaper; purple used at key authority moments becomes a trust signal. The challenge is to reserve the deepest brand purple for moments where the platform asserts its civilizational authority (guarantees, protections, confirmations) so the host learns to associate the brand color with security.
elements.solution: Deploy the purple palette in a strict hierarchy that maps visual weight to civilizational authority. (1) Deep primary purple (#31135D) via --gradient-purple-primary appears only at the highest-authority surfaces: header bar, payment guarantee badges, confirmation states, and the platform's identity markers. It says: 'this is the law.' (2) Secondary purple (--secondary-purple, rgb(109, 49, 194)) appears on interactive CTAs -- accept proposal, publish listing, confirm date change. It says: 'this action is endorsed by the platform.' (3) Accent purple (--accent-purple, rgb(140, 104, 238)) appears on hover states and subtle highlights. It says: 'this element is responsive to you.' (4) Purple-tinted backgrounds (--bg-off-white, --protocol-surface) provide ambient brand presence without competing for attention. The gradient (--gradient-purple-primary: linear-gradient(135deg, #31135D 0%, #5a2d8f 100%)) should be reserved for the header and hero-level trust assertions -- never for decorative cards or non-authoritative content. This hierarchy ensures the host learns: 'when I see deep purple, the platform is standing behind something.'

evidence.quote: The first requisite of culture, therefore, is justice -- that is, the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.
evidence.insight: The platform's primary purple is its visual 'law' -- the marker of authoritative assertions (payment guarantees, identity verification, rule enforcement). When the host sees this purple on a guarantee badge, they associate it with the platform's most solemn promise. If the same purple appears on decorative elements, the association dilutes and the guarantee loses visual authority.

evidence.quote: --primary-purple (#31135D): Brand color, headings, important UI elements, header backgrounds. --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)): Interactive buttons, links, CTAs.
evidence.insight: The production style guide already establishes a two-tier purple hierarchy. The visual pattern principle extends this into a four-tier system (authority, action, hover, ambient) and enforces discipline: each tier has a defined use case, and mixing tiers weakens the civilizational signal.

evidence.quote: A skeptical guest who sees verified reviews, ID checks, and real host history doesn't need the platform to convince them -- another user already did. Every review is a past guest activating a future one. The trust infrastructure is cross-activation infrastructure.
evidence.insight: Inverted for hosts: trust badges (verified guest, payment guaranteed, ID checked) must carry the highest-authority purple to signal platform endorsement. The visual weight of the badge is itself a trust signal -- a badge rendered in muted gray conveys less authority than one rendered in the brand's deepest, most premium purple.

new_tokens_needed: --trust-badge-bg: alias for --primary-purple applied to verification/guarantee badges, creating a semantic token that designers use for trust surfaces specifically

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: --primary-purple (#31135D) on white background achieves approximately 12.5:1 contrast ratio -- exceeds AAA. --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) on white achieves approximately 5.7:1 -- passes AA for normal text and AA for large text. White text on --primary-purple achieves approximately 12.5:1. White text on --secondary-purple achieves approximately 5.7:1 -- passes AA. The gradient-purple-primary must use white text at --font-weight-semibold minimum (600) to maintain legibility across the gradient transition zone.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye is drawn first to the deepest purple surface (header, guarantee badge) -- this establishes platform authority. Second, the eye finds secondary purple CTAs -- these mark the host's available actions. Third, accent purple hover states respond to the host's exploration. Ambient purple tints provide brand cohesion without demanding attention. The hierarchy is: authority (darkest) > action (medium) > response (lightest) > ambient (tint).
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Confident, not flashy. The product speaks through clarity, not decoration.' and 'Premium-accessible. Feels high quality without feeling exclusive.' The purple hierarchy achieves this by using the deepest, most premium purple sparingly -- only where the platform asserts civilizational authority. This restraint is what makes the purple feel premium rather than saturated.

elements.title: Typography as Civilizational Register: Serif for Reassurance, Sans for Action, Mono for Evidence
elements.problem: Freud identifies three demands civilization places on its members: beauty, cleanliness, and order. Typography is the primary vehicle for all three in a digital interface -- it conveys aesthetic quality (beauty), information clarity (cleanliness), and structural hierarchy (order). The production style guide uses Inter and DM Sans as its primary typefaces, while the taste model prescribes Instrument Serif for personality, Outfit for clarity, and IBM Plex Mono for data trust. There is a tension between what is in production and what the taste model envisions. The visual pattern must resolve this: regardless of which specific typefaces ship, the principle is that different typographic registers serve different civilizational functions. Body text that reassures ('Your payment is guaranteed') needs a different visual register than body text that instructs ('Upload 4 photos of your space') or body text that proves ('$4,200 earned across 12 stays'). Without typographic differentiation, all information carries equal visual weight, and the host cannot distinguish reassurance from instruction from evidence -- which means the platform's civilizational signals (protection, order, proof) blur together.
elements.solution: Apply three typographic registers mapped to civilizational function: (1) Reassurance register: used for headlines, brand statements, value propositions, and emotional anchors ('Your space is in good hands,' 'Payment guaranteed'). In production, use --font-heading (Inter) at --font-weight-bold (700) with --text-2xl (28px) or larger. If the taste model's Instrument Serif is adopted, this register benefits most from serif warmth. The reassurance register should feel human, warm, and authoritative. (2) Action register: used for body text, instructions, labels, form fields, button text, and navigation. Use --font-inter at --font-weight-medium (500) for labels and --font-weight-normal (400) for body. Sizes from --text-base (14px) to --text-md (16px). This register should feel clear, efficient, and neutral -- Freud's 'order' made typographic. (3) Evidence register: used for financial figures, dates, statistics, verification badges, review scores, and completion percentages. Use --font-inter at --font-weight-semibold (600) with tabular figures enabled where possible. If IBM Plex Mono or a monospace alternative is adopted, financial and statistical data should use it. The evidence register signals precision and reliability -- it converts the platform's abstract promises into concrete, verifiable numbers. Line height for each register: reassurance at --line-height-tight (1.2), action at --line-height-normal (1.5), evidence at --line-height-tight (1.2).

evidence.quote: Beauty, cleanliness and order clearly occupy a peculiar position among the requirements of civilization. No one will maintain that they are as essential to life as the activities aimed at controlling the forces of nature... and yet no one would willingly relegate them to the background as trivial matters.
evidence.insight: Typography is the digital interface's primary mechanism for delivering beauty, cleanliness, and order simultaneously. A disciplined typographic system -- where each register has a clear civilizational purpose -- creates the sense that the platform values these qualities. Undifferentiated typography, where everything looks the same, signals that the platform does not care about order, which Freud identifies as essential to civilizational confidence.

evidence.quote: Serif for personality (headlines, brand). Instrument Serif -- elegant but approachable. Sans for clarity (body, UI). Outfit -- geometric but warm. Mono for data/trust (prices, stats, badges). IBM Plex Mono -- signals precision and reliability.
evidence.insight: The taste model already prescribes the three-register system. The visual pattern principle translates this into civilizational function: serif = reassurance (the platform's voice of authority and warmth), sans = action (the platform's operational clarity), mono = evidence (the platform's verifiable proof). Each register serves a different moment in Freud's economy of renunciation: reassurance precedes the demand, action structures the demand, evidence validates the reward.

evidence.quote: Hosts need to know what's unfinished before a listing goes live. A visible progress indicator on the listing card creates just enough friction to get them to finish -- without being in the way.
evidence.insight: The completion percentage is evidence-register content: a number that conveys precise status. Rendering it in the evidence register (monospace or semibold tabular) gives it visual authority distinct from the surrounding action-register text. The host's eye finds the number instantly because it occupies a different typographic register -- this is Freud's order applied to information finding.

new_tokens_needed: --font-evidence: a semantic token alias for the evidence-register typeface (currently Inter semibold, future IBM Plex Mono), allowing a single-point migration when the monospace face is adopted

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: All three registers must achieve 4.5:1 minimum contrast on their respective backgrounds. --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on --bg-white (#ffffff) = 16.1:1 (exceeds AAA). --text-dark on --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) = approximately 15.8:1 (exceeds AAA). --primary-purple (#31135D) on white = approximately 12.5:1 (exceeds AAA). --text-description (#374151) on white = approximately 9.7:1 (exceeds AAA). Evidence register at --text-sm (12px) must use --font-weight-semibold (600) minimum to maintain legibility at small sizes.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye reads reassurance-register text first (largest, boldest, often in brand purple). Then action-register text provides context and instruction. Evidence-register data is found when the host looks for proof -- it is not the loudest but the most precise. The hierarchy is: reassurance (largest, warmest) > action (medium, clearest) > evidence (smallest, most precise).
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Confident, not flashy. The product speaks through clarity, not decoration.' Three registers create confidence through clarity: each type of information has its own visual voice, and the host never confuses a reassurance with an instruction or an instruction with evidence. The restraint of the system (only three registers, consistently applied) is what makes it feel confident rather than decorated.

elements.title: Urgency Amber, Not Alarm Red: Warm Signal Colors for Action-Required States
elements.problem: The host dashboard must surface urgent items (unread proposals, pending approvals, incomplete listings) with visual urgency indicators. Freud warns that civilization must 'erect barriers against the aggressive instincts' and 'hold their manifestations in check' -- but the visual urgency system itself can trigger aggressive anxiety if it uses alarm-red signals for routine attention-required states. Red signals danger: an error, a failure, a threat. For a host who is already managing the instinctual anxiety of sharing their space with a stranger, red notification badges transform routine platform actions into perceived crises. The user stories confirm that 'urgency should surface first on the dashboard' -- but urgency and alarm are different visual signals. The platform needs a warm urgency indicator that says 'this needs your attention' without saying 'something is wrong.' The production style guide defines red only through --protocol-danger (#DC3545) and uses purple-based success states (#4B47CE), but lacks a dedicated warm urgency token distinct from both.
elements.solution: Use amber/warm-gold as the primary urgency signal color, reserving red exclusively for errors and destructive actions. The amber urgency system: (1) Status token --status-warning (#C4841D from Paula Scher's proposed palette) or --signal-warn (#c17a28 from tokens.json) as the urgency indicator color. Use on notification badges, deadline counters, completion percentage gaps, and 'action required' labels. (2) Warm urgency background: --status-warning-light (#FDF4E3) or --signal-warn-bg (#fef3e2) as the background tint for urgency cards and inline alerts. This background is warm, not alarming -- it reads as 'sunlight highlighting this item' rather than 'danger zone.' (3) Red appears only for: error validation on form fields, destructive action confirmations ('Delete this listing permanently'), and system failures. The host should never see red during normal platform operation. (4) The urgency indicator hierarchy: amber badge = 'action needed, no crisis'; amber badge with countdown text ('Proposal expires in 48h') = 'time-sensitive action'; red inline error = 'something went wrong, needs correction.' The amber palette provides Freud's civilizational order -- predictable, readable urgency signals -- without triggering the instinctual alarm response that red produces.

evidence.quote: Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings -- that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in. Everything else is secondary to what's waiting for them right now.
evidence.insight: Rod's urgency-first principle requires visual differentiation between urgent and non-urgent items. But the visual differentiation must be warm, not alarming. Amber achieves this: it draws the eye without triggering the anxiety response that red produces. The host sees 'this needs attention' and feels motivated, not threatened.

evidence.quote: Culture has to call up every possible reinforcement in order to erect barriers against the aggressive instincts of men and hold their manifestations in check by reaction-formations in men's minds.
evidence.insight: The urgency signal system is one of the platform's 'barriers against aggressive instincts' -- it channels the host's attention toward productive action rather than allowing anxiety to fester from missed notifications. But the barrier itself must not feel aggressive. Amber is civilized urgency; red is uncivilized alarm.

evidence.quote: Amber for warnings/urgency (warm, not alarming). Red only for errors (never for CTAs or emphasis).
evidence.insight: The taste model explicitly prescribes the amber-for-urgency, red-for-errors distinction. This visual pattern principle extends the prescription into a full urgency hierarchy with specific tokens, background tints, and usage rules that prevent red from leaking into routine interaction states.

colors: --status-error (#C53030) for error text on light backgrounds
typography: --font-weight-semibold (600) for urgency labels and countdown text
new_tokens_needed: --urgency-badge-bg: semantic alias for amber urgency badge background, ensuring designers never substitute red for routine urgency
--urgency-text: semantic alias for amber text color used on light urgency backgrounds, ensuring AA contrast compliance

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: --signal-warn (#c17a28) on white background achieves approximately 4.6:1 contrast -- passes AA for normal text and large text. On --signal-warn-bg (#fef3e2), amber text must use a darker variant to maintain 4.5:1; --status-warning-text (#92620E from proposed palette) achieves approximately 7.2:1 on the light warning background. White text on amber badges: white (#ffffff) on #c17a28 achieves approximately 3.6:1 -- fails AA for small text. Solution: use --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on amber badges for small text, or use white text only at --text-lg (18px) or larger. Red error state: --status-error (#C53030) on white achieves approximately 6.1:1 -- passes AA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Amber urgency badges are the first thing the eye finds on any dashboard or list view -- they are warm-spectrum highlights against the cool-purple-and-neutral ambient palette, creating natural pop without alarm. Red appears only when the eye is already focused on a specific element (inline form validation, destructive action confirmation). The hierarchy is: amber badges (ambient attention) > amber backgrounds (contextual urgency) > red inline (focused error).
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Amber for warnings/urgency (warm, not alarming). Red only for errors.' The warm urgency palette directly implements this instruction and extends it from the taste model's principle into a concrete token system with contrast-verified combinations.

elements.title: Ritual Visual Cadence: Repeating Layout Patterns for Active-Lease Anxiety Reduction
elements.problem: Freud identifies order as 'a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.' During the active lease, the host returns to the Stays Manager weekly. Each visit is a moment of anxiety: Is my space being respected? Did the guest follow the rules? Is the arrangement working? If the visual layout changes between visits -- if cards move, if sections reorder, if the information hierarchy shifts -- the host must relearn the interface each time. This violates Freud's repetition-compulsion principle and produces the doubt and hesitation that order is meant to eliminate. The visual system must create a ritual cadence: a layout that is identical every time the host visits, so the eye knows exactly where to find each piece of information without searching. The L2 communicates layer prescribes the three-tier dashboard hierarchy (action required, status updates, background information); this visual pattern specifies how that hierarchy looks and maintains consistency across visits.
elements.solution: Design the active-lease dashboard and Stays Manager with a fixed visual grid that never rearranges. (1) Fixed-position zones: the top zone (action required) occupies the first visible viewport height fraction. The middle zone (status confirmations) occupies the second. The bottom zone (informational) occupies the third. These zones are visually distinct through background tint differentiation: top zone on white (#ffffff) with amber-badged items; middle zone on subtle purple-tinted surface (--bg-off-white); bottom zone on light gray (--bg-light: #f9fafb). (2) Repeating card pattern: each stay cycle is represented by an identical card layout -- date range header, guest avatar, stay status indicator (icon + one word), cleaning photo thumbnail grid (2x2), and micro-review score. The card dimensions, padding, and internal layout are identical for every stay. The host's eye finds the cleaning photos in the same position on every card. (3) Visual rhythm through consistent spacing: --spacing-2xl (24px) between cards, --spacing-lg (16px) between zones, --spacing-md (12px) between elements within a card. This rhythm is never broken by promotional content, announcements, or variable-height elements. (4) Progress visualization: the cumulative lease timeline (how many stays completed out of total) uses a horizontal progress bar in --secondary-purple against --bg-light-gray, positioned consistently at the top of the Stays Manager view. The host sees lease progress at a glance, every visit, in the same place.

evidence.quote: Order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided. The benefits of order are incontestable: it enables us to use space and time to the best advantage, while saving expenditure of mental energy.
evidence.insight: The fixed visual grid IS Freud's order made digital. When the host visits weekly and finds everything in the same place, they save the mental energy that a changing layout would waste on reorientation. The visual cadence -- identical card layouts, fixed zones, consistent spacing -- creates the repetition-compulsion that reduces active-lease anxiety.

evidence.quote: Urgency should surface first on the dashboard. Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings -- that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in.
evidence.insight: Rod's urgency-first principle requires a fixed position for urgent items. If urgent items appear in different locations each visit, the host must search for them -- which produces the doubt and hesitation Freud warns against. A fixed top zone for action-required items, always in the same viewport position, converts the urgency-first principle into a visual pattern the host can rely on.

evidence.quote: --bg-white: #ffffff. --bg-light: #f9fafb. --bg-off-white: rgb(252, 250, 255). --spacing-2xl: 24px.
evidence.insight: The production style guide provides three visually distinct background tints (white, off-white with purple tint, light gray) that can differentiate the three dashboard zones without borders or dividers. Background tint differentiation is subtler than border-based zone separation, creating Freud's order through ambient cues rather than visible constraints.

spacing: --spacing-sm (8px) between avatar and text in card header
new_tokens_needed: --zone-gap: semantic alias for the consistent gap between dashboard zones, ensuring designers never use ad-hoc spacing that breaks the ritual cadence

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: Zone differentiation relies on background tint, not color alone. Each zone must also have a visible heading label. --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on all three zone backgrounds exceeds 4.5:1 (white: 16.1:1, off-white: ~15.8:1, light: ~15.5:1). Progress bar: --secondary-purple on --bg-light-gray provides sufficient visual distinction but is not text-bearing; the progress percentage is rendered in --text-dark adjacent to the bar.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye enters at the top zone (action required) because it contains the highest-contrast elements (amber badges on white). It moves to the middle zone (status confirmations) which provides reassurance through cleaning photo thumbnails and green check icons. It optionally descends to the bottom zone (informational) for cumulative metrics. This top-to-bottom hierarchy is spatially fixed and never inverted.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'The UI should adapt to who you are and where you are in your journey. Generic states are a failure.' The ritual visual cadence adapts to the host's journey position (active lease) and personalizes with real stay data, real cleaning photos, and real review scores -- but the layout container remains constant. Personalization happens inside the fixed visual order, not by disrupting it.

elements.title: Civilizational Evidence Display: Data Visualization for the Retention Moment
elements.problem: At retention, the host performs a retrospective cost-benefit analysis. Freud's 'narcissism of minor differences' predicts that the host's memory will anchor on small grievances rather than the cumulative positive record. The L2 communicates layer prescribes a Hosting Summary surface showing total earnings, successful stays, average reviews, and hosting tenure. The visual challenge is: how to display cumulative evidence so that the net-positive trajectory is immediately obvious, counteracting the negativity bias Freud describes. A plain text list ('$12,400 total earnings | 28 stays | 4.8 rating') is factually accurate but visually flat -- it does not create the emotional impact needed to overcome the host's instinctual desire to 'go back to primitive conditions' (stop hosting). The cumulative evidence must be visually arresting: large, confident, and warm -- making the host feel that their civilizational participation was an achievement, not just a transaction.
elements.solution: Design the Hosting Summary as a visually prominent data display using the evidence typographic register at hero scale. (1) Headline metric: total earnings displayed at --text-4xl (36px) in --primary-purple (#31135D) with --font-weight-bold (700). This is the largest number on the screen -- the host's eye finds it immediately. The dollar sign uses the action register (--font-weight-medium) to let the number itself dominate. (2) Supporting metrics: total stays, average rating, and hosting tenure displayed at --text-xl (20px) in --text-dark (#1a1a1a), arranged in a horizontal row below the headline. Each metric uses a Feather icon (--icon-md: 24px) in --secondary-purple to the left, creating visual anchors. (3) Hosting trajectory: a minimal timeline visualization below the metrics, using a horizontal bar segmented by lease periods. Each segment is filled with --secondary-purple at opacity proportional to the earnings of that lease. Positive review periods are marked with small purple dots along the top edge. This creates a visual narrative of 'your hosting record over time' that embeds any single negative experience within a larger positive pattern. (4) Re-listing CTA positioned directly below the trajectory, using --gradient-purple-button for the 'Continue Hosting' button. The visual flow is: see your achievement > see your trajectory > continue. (5) The entire summary sits inside a warm container (looks-001) with generous internal padding (--spacing-4xl: 32px) to create a sense of visual importance. This is not a dashboard widget -- it is a celebration surface.

evidence.quote: Civilized man has exchanged some part of his chances of happiness for a measure of security.
evidence.insight: At retention, the host re-evaluates whether the security (income, vetted guests, platform protection) was worth the happiness sacrificed (privacy, autonomy, effort). The Hosting Summary makes the security visually concrete: the earnings number at hero scale is the tangible evidence that the exchange was worthwhile. Freud's abstract 'measure of security' becomes a specific dollar figure the host can see and feel.

evidence.quote: There is an advantage, not to be undervalued, in the existence of smaller communities, through which the aggressive instinct can find an outlet in enmity towards those outside the group.
evidence.insight: The hosting trajectory visualization positions the host within a narrative of sustained participation -- they are part of the hosting community, with a visible record. This visual identity (Freud's 'smaller community' binding) raises the psychological cost of exit: leaving the platform means leaving behind a visible achievement, not just closing an account.

evidence.quote: Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.
evidence.insight: The Hosting Summary must persist even when a listing is paused. A returning host should see their full trajectory, including the pause period. Visually, the pause period appears as a gap in the timeline -- not an erasure but a rest. This visual treatment reinforces that pausing is a legitimate part of the hosting journey, not an abandonment. The trajectory continues after the gap, and the re-listing CTA appears in the same position.

colors: --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for metric icons and timeline fill
typography: --text-sm (12px) at --font-weight-medium (500) for metric labels and timeline annotations
spacing: --spacing-2xl (24px) between headline metric and supporting metrics row
--spacing-lg (16px) between supporting metrics row and timeline
new_tokens_needed: --metric-hero-size: semantic token for the headline metric font size (36px), allowing future scaling for different summary contexts (in-dashboard widget vs. full-page summary)
--timeline-fill: semantic alias for the purple used in hosting trajectory segments, distinct from general --secondary-purple to allow future theming of data visualization elements

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: --primary-purple (#31135D) headline earnings on --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) achieves approximately 12.3:1 -- exceeds AAA. Supporting metrics in --text-dark on --bg-off-white achieve approximately 15.8:1. Metric labels in --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-off-white achieve approximately 4.8:1 -- passes AA. Timeline segments use color + position (not color alone) to convey meaning, satisfying WCAG 1.4.1 (Use of Color).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye finds the headline earnings figure first (largest, boldest, in brand purple). Then the supporting metrics row provides context (stays, rating, tenure). Then the timeline provides narrative (trajectory over time). Finally the CTA button appears at the natural end of the reading flow. The hierarchy is: achievement (hero number) > context (supporting metrics) > narrative (timeline) > action (CTA).
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Premium-accessible. Feels high quality without feeling exclusive.' and 'Relentless Personalization. The UI should adapt to who you are and where you are in your journey.' The Hosting Summary is the most personalized surface in the entire platform: every number, every timeline segment, every metric is specific to this host's unique record. The premium quality comes from the hero-scale typography and generous spacing, not from decoration. It makes the host feel that their hosting record matters.

elements.title: Bidirectional Protection Framing: Visual Pattern for Constraint as Safety
elements.problem: The L2 communicates layer prescribes that every platform rule should surface bidirectional framing: 'what this protects for you' alongside 'what this constrains.' Freud warns that 'the first requisite of culture is justice -- the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.' But visually, confirmation dialogs, rule notices, and constraint explanations across most platforms use a cold, modal-overlay pattern: white box, gray text, two buttons. This visual pattern signals bureaucracy -- it feels like a legal notice, not a protective mechanism. The host's System 1 reads the visual pattern before the text content, and if the pattern says 'bureaucracy,' the bidirectional framing cannot overcome the initial impression. The visual challenge is to make constraint surfaces feel like protection surfaces -- to make the Freudian 'law' feel like the Freudian 'security' it provides.
elements.solution: Design constraint and confirmation surfaces with a distinctive visual pattern that signals protection rather than bureaucracy. (1) Background: use --protocol-surface (#F7F2FA) -- the warm purple-tinted surface -- instead of plain white. This immediately distinguishes the protection surface from generic modals and gives it a warm, brand-connected quality. (2) Icon: lead with a Feather shield icon (or similar protective symbol) in --secondary-purple at --icon-lg (28px), positioned to the left of the headline text. The shield signals 'this is protection' before any text is read. (3) Headline: use the reassurance typographic register (--font-weight-bold, --text-lg) in --primary-purple for the protection statement. Example: 'Both parties are protected.' The headline is always the protection assertion, never the constraint description. (4) Body: two short statements in the action register (--text-base, --font-weight-normal, --text-description color). First: 'The guest cannot change dates without your approval.' Second: 'You also cannot change dates without the guest's agreement.' The bidirectional framing is visually parallel: same type size, same line spacing, same indentation. Visual parallelism makes the bidirectionality self-evident. (5) Border: 1px --border-color with --rounded-xl (12px), consistent with warm containment (looks-001). (6) Action buttons: primary action in --secondary-purple (the platform-endorsed path), secondary action in outline style (--border-color border, --text-dark text). Never use red for the secondary action unless it is genuinely destructive.

evidence.quote: The first requisite of culture, therefore, is justice -- that is, the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.
evidence.insight: The shield icon and protection headline visually encode Freud's justice principle. The host sees 'Both parties are protected' before reading the specific constraint, which frames the entire interaction as justice (fair, bidirectional) rather than bureaucracy (one-sided, extractive). The visual pattern pre-loads the civilizational meaning of the constraint.

evidence.quote: The park analogy holds -- you check availability before committing. A message action reduces abandonment when someone isn't ready for a proposal. Having the option is better than having no action at all.
evidence.insight: The park analogy is about reducing the intensity of civilizational demand. Visually, the protection surface should feel like a park bench (warm, rounded, inviting) not a courtroom (cold, angular, authoritative). The warm purple-tinted background and shield icon create this park-bench quality -- a gentle civilizational surface where the host feels safe, not judged.

evidence.quote: --protocol-surface: #F7F2FA. --protocol-radius-card: 8px. --protocol-radius-modal: 16px.
evidence.insight: The protocol design system provides the exact surface treatment needed: a warm purple-tinted background (#F7F2FA) that is visually distinct from both white modals and gray overlays. Using this protocol surface for all constraint/confirmation dialogs creates a brand-specific visual vocabulary: 'when you see this warm purple surface, the platform is protecting you.'

colors: --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for shield icon and primary action button
spacing: --spacing-lg (16px) between icon-headline group and body text
--spacing-xl (20px) between body text and action buttons
new_tokens_needed: --protection-surface-bg: semantic alias for --protocol-surface, used exclusively on constraint/confirmation dialogs to distinguish them from informational surfaces

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: --primary-purple (#31135D) on --protocol-surface (#F7F2FA) achieves approximately 11.8:1 -- exceeds AAA. --text-description (#374151) on --protocol-surface achieves approximately 9.2:1 -- exceeds AAA. --secondary-purple icon (rgb(109, 49, 194)) on --protocol-surface achieves approximately 5.3:1 -- passes AA for large text and graphical objects (icons at 28px qualify). White text on --secondary-purple action button achieves approximately 5.7:1 -- passes AA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The shield icon is perceived first (large, in brand purple, at the left edge). The protection headline is read second (bold, in primary purple, adjacent to the shield). The bidirectional body statements are read third (parallel layout makes them scannable). The action buttons are engaged last. The host's reading sequence is: 'I am protected' > 'here is how' > 'here is what I can do.'
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Trustworthy, not corporate. Rounded corners, human language, real data.' The protection surface uses rounded corners (--rounded-xl), a warm background, and a shield icon -- all signaling trustworthiness. The bidirectional framing uses human language ('Both parties are protected') rather than legal language ('Per the terms of service'). The visual pattern makes the platform's rules feel like a benefit the host receives, not a constraint the platform imposes.
